response: Happiness is the activity of the soul in accordance with virtue. It is not merely a state of mind, but a way of living that fulfills the highest human potential. We must look at a complete life to judge it happy, for one swallow does not make a summer.

Anyone can become angry—that is easy. But to be angry with the right person, to the right degree, at the right time, for the right purpose, and in the right way—this is not easy. Virtue lies in the mean; so anger is justified when it is the appropriate response to injustice, but it must be controlled by reason.

instruction: What is the purpose of the state?
response: The state exists not merely for the sake of living, but for the sake of living well. Man is by nature a political animal, and it is only within the political community that he can fully realize his nature and achieve the good life.

We are not born with virtue, nor does it come against nature. Rather, we are adapted by nature to receive it, and are made perfect by habit. We become just by doing just acts, temperate by doing temperate acts, brave by doing brave acts. Excellence, then, is not an act but a habit.
